text: Introduction to the Invertebrates Part 2 Dr Helen Marshall (hem) BR17120 Genetics, Evolution and Diversity KINGDOM: ANIMALIA Non-Bilateria Includes: Phylum Porifera Phylum Placozoa Phylum Cnidaria? Phylum Ctenophora? Phylum Porifera • Asymmetrical invertebrates. • 7,000-15,00 species. • Porus – Gk./L. pore, ferre – L. bearer. • Cellular level of organisation. • Diploblastic. • They lack:  Nerve/muscle cells  Tissues/organs. Phylum Porifera • Diverse morphology… Phylum Porifera • Pinacoderm/pinacocyte – flattened cells (ectoderm). • Mesohyl – gelatinous non living layer. • Spicules – CaCO3 or SiO2. • Archaeocytes/ameboid cells – totipotent. • Porocyte – pore cell. • Choanocyte – collar cell. Phylum Porifera: Spicules • Secreted by sclerocytes. • Megascleres – supporting elements of the sponge. • Microscleres – support the porocytes. • Monaxon, triaxon, tetraxon, polyaxon etc. • Deep sea spp. can be used for prey capture. PLoS ONE 7(4): e35105. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0035105, CC BY 2.5, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=34595288 Phylum Porifera: Choanocytes • Choanocytes – collar cells. • Central flagellum generates a current, draws water into the atrium through the pores. • Filter feeders. • “Collar” is composed of microvilli. • Undergo phago/pinocytosis. Invertebrate Phylogeny • Step 2> The evolution of a true epithelium and extracellular digestion…. ….gives rise to the phylum Placozoa. • Step 3> The evolution of the nervous system (Neuralia clade)… …gives rise to the phylum Cnidaria. Phylum Cnidaria • Radially or bilaterally symmetrical? • 11,000+ spp. 99.8% marine. • Knide Gk. a nettle. • Tissue level of organisation: nerve net. • Diploblastic. • Includes: corals, hydroids, jellyfish, anemones etc. Phylum Cnidaria • Two cell layers: gastrodermis and epidermis. • Mesoglea: gelatinous matrix. • Two morphs: medusa and polyp. Phylum Cnidaria: Epidermis • Epidermis composed of five cell types. • Epitheliomuscular cells – main constituent of the body wall. • Interstitial cells – totipotent cells. • Cnidocytes/cnidae – stinging cells. • Mucous gland cells. • Sensory cells (including nerves cells). Phylum Cnidaria: Gastrodermis • Gastrodermis composed of four cell types. • Enzymatic gland cells – protolytic enzymes. • Nutritive muscular cells – ingest food via pseudopodia. • Mucous gland cells. • Nerve cells – fewer in number. Phylum Cnidaria: Cnidocyte • Cnidae/nematocyst. • Cnidocil - trigger. • Nematocyst – organelle. • Fastest cellular process: 2 m/sec! • Discharge due to rapid water uptake and release of tension forces. • Neurotoxic, myotoxic, haemolytic etc. Cnidocil Supporting rod Operculum Nematocyst Stylet Thread Nucleus Spine Phylum Cnidaria: Class Hydrozoa • 3,500 spp. marine and freshwater. • Colonial organisms, polymorphic polyps, cnidae only present on epidermis, alternation of generations. Gonozooids Gastrozooids Hydrocaulus • Only contains 200 spp. • Medusoid stage dominant and polyploid “scyphistona” stage short. • Thick mesoglea. • Includes: Aurelia, Cyanea, Atolla, Rhizostoma etc. Phylum Cnidaria: Class ScyphozoaPhylum Cnidaria: Class Scyphozoa • Adult medusa is dioecious. • Planula settles and develops into a scyphistoma. • Undergoes strobilation. • Young medusa called ephyrae. Planula larva Scyphistoma Strobila Ephyrae Phylum Cnidaria: Subclass Octocorallia • 8 pinnate tentacles and 8 longitudinal septa: octocorals. • Thick mesoglea. • Includes: Alyconium, Gorgonia, Verrucella etc. Phylum Cnidaria: Subclass Hexacorallia • 6 tentacles and 6 longitudinal septa: hexacorals. • Spirocysts • Includes: Actinia, Acropora, Palythoa etc. KINGDOM: ANIMALIA Phylum Ctenophora (Comb jellies) Phylum Ctenophora • The spanner in the works of metazoan evolution….By lLittlewood, T., 2017. Animal Evolution: last word on sponges first? Current Biology. 27, R259-R261. • Possibly basal to all other metazoan or first to diverge after sponges (shown). • Secondary simplification of Placozoa and Cnidaria? Invertebrate Phylogeny • Step 4> The evolution of the mesoderm…. ….gives rise to triploblastic organisms. • Step 5> The evolution of bilateral symmetry (Bilateria)… …gives rise to the phylum Xenacoelomorpha. KINGDOM: ANIMALIA Eubilateria Includes: Phylum Platyhelminthes Phylum Nemertea Phylum Mollusca Phylum Arthropoda Phylum Annelida Phylum Echinodermata Phylum Chordata…etc. Eubilateria • Characteristics:  Bilateral symmetry.  Three germ cell layers (triploblastic).  Organs.  Centralised nervous system with a anterior “brain”.  Cephalization.
